content:
In Buddhism, the concept of "emptiness" (shunyata) does not describe where things arise from, but rather what things are. Emptiness is the idea that all things lack an inherent or independent existence, and that their existence is dependent on conditions and causes.

In this view, things arise from the interplay of conditions and causes, but their existence is not considered to come from a single source or to be caused by a single entity. Instead, things are seen as arising in dependence on the collective interplay of conditions and causes, and as being contingent and impermanent.

So, in Buddhism, the idea of emptiness does not describe where things come from, but rather the nature of reality and the dependent origination of all things.
